resources.string: Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and typesetting industry
I have read and acknowledged the Terms & Services
Please enter your phone number to verify your account

IMPORTANT! PLEASE READ!

Please continue using the given id convention: For any item on your XML file, do:
 android:id = +@+id/activityName_viewType_nameOfView
For example, an EditText in HomeFragment that will hold the app's name should have an id like "@+id/homeFragment_editText_appName". 
Similarly, "@+id/homeFragment_layout_top" is the id of the Layout(constraint) on top of HomeFragment.

Also, continue using this convention in your Java files as well: For example, do something like 
ViewType viewType_viewName
when naming views. For example, something like
EditText editText_appName
would work for the previous example. All this is because when you call findViewById(R.id.) function, android studio lists ALL views on the ENTIRE project. Everything gets mixed up if we don't use a naming convention that uses descriptive names.

Also, adding functionality to a Fragment is similar to an Activity. In summary, instead of Activity OnCreate method, you write your code in Fragment onCreateView method. Instead of creating an Intent and startActivity method to change into another screen, you use loadFragment method. Refer to implemented fragments to see this method. There are more things to discuss here, but see HomeFragment and ProfileFragment as working examples of Fragments and for further information. If there are functionalities you wish to add to a fragment, you can ask me about them.
 GL

 NullPointerException xd
